There's also an argument that, well, there's a lot of single mothers who have to go get the lowest prices they can.
They're struggling to get along, and if you're buying toilet paper or, you know, food for that matter, Wal-Mart, they've got really good prices.
Oh absolutely, and again, people are free to make their own choices.

But what I found in the course of doing this research, between 2000 and 2007, the median family income dropped in the United States by about $1,175, adjusting for inflation, while our spending increased by over $4,500.
So yet as we were spending what seemed like less and less on consumer goods, we were spending more and more money.
So the price of clothing, for example, dropped by about 32 percent.
The price of appliances dropped by about 52 percent.
But at the same time, the price of health insurance increased by 74 percent.
The price of mortgages increased by 76 percent.
So while we were able to get consumer goods cheaper and cheaper, our fixed costs, the things about which we don't have any choices, increased.
And at the same time, our wages and benefits decreased.
So in a way, cheap consumer goods is a little like bread and circuses.
Yes, you can get, you know, tube tops and maybe ground beef at a lower price - not always, by the way, but maybe you can.
But what does that mean in terms of your own benefits and wages?
It's not just - when we're competing with the developing world for wages and benefits, we're going to lose.
